plants.name: Prunus serrulata
plants.description: A deciduous tree famous for its spectacular spring blossoms, often celebrated in festivals, this species produces clusters of delicate pink to white flowers that typically bloom in early spring.
plants.location: Japan, East Asia, cultivated worldwide in temperate climates
plants.funFact: The blooming of cherry blossoms is so culturally significant in Japan that the government tracks and predicts peak bloom dates each year.

plants.name: Magnolia x soulangeana
plants.description: A large deciduous shrub or small tree known for its early spring display of large, tulip-shaped flowers that emerge before the leaves, with colors ranging from white to deep pink and purple.
plants.location: Native to China, widely cultivated in temperate regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Magnolias are among the earliest flowering plants, with fossil records dating back 95 million years, predating bees; they are thought to have been pollinated by beetles.

plants.name: Narcissus pseudonarcissus
plants.description: A wild species of daffodil producing bright yellow, trumpet-shaped flowers in clusters on leafless stems, often found in woodlands and meadows.
plants.location: Western Europe, particularly the UK and Ireland
plants.funFact: The wild daffodil is the original species from which many garden varieties have been bred; it is a symbol of spring in many cultures.

plants.name: Eucalyptus globulus
plants.description: A tall evergreen tree known for its aromatic leaves and clusters of creamy white flowers that bloom profusely in early spring, important for honey production.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late Winter to Spring (February to April)
plants.location: Native to southeastern Australia, widely planted in Mediterranean and subtropical climates worldwide
plants.funFact: Blue Gum Eucalyptus flowers have no petals; what appear as flowers are dense clusters of stamens, which are highly attractive to pollinators like bees.
